oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tolbert Fanning
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Teachers; Scholars
Agriculture; Fanning, Tolbert, 1810-1874; Geology
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait to the shoulders of Tolbert Fanning appears as an oval image within a squared cropping on page 6 of the book "Franklin College and Its Influences" by James E. Scobey.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Scobey, James E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tolbert Fanning led the early efforts of the Stone-Campbell Movement in Tennessee and came to be seen as one of the most prominent Disciples of Christ in the state and in the South. He was heavily influenced by Gerard Troost in his fascination with agriculture and geology. He edited and published agricultural and scientific journals and touted the benefits of scientific agriculture. He founded Franklin College which advocated scientific study, practical application in the
